questions.conceptTested: Right to access vs right to use
questions.question: A software company licenses intellectual property that provides a right to access the IP as it exists throughout the license period. Revenue should be recognized:

options.A: At the point in time when the license is granted
options.B: Over time as the customer benefits from access
options.C: Only when cash is collected

questions.explanation: A license providing a 'right to access' (IP changes during the license, such as a brand) is recognized over time. A 'right to use' license (static IP, like software at a point in time) is recognized when control transfers.
questions.tip: Right to access (dynamic IP) = over time. Right to use (static IP) = point in time.

questions.question: A product warranty that covers defects existing at sale (assurance-type warranty) should be accounted for as:

options.A: A separate performance obligation with allocated revenue
options.B: An estimated liability accrued at the time of sale
options.C: Deferred revenue until warranty period expires
options.D: A contingent liability disclosed but not recorded

questions.explanation: Assurance-type warranties (product works as promised) are not separate performance obligations. They're accounted for under ASC 460 as warranty liabilities. Service-type warranties (extended warranties) are separate performance obligations.
questions.tip: Assurance warranty = liability. Service/extended warranty = separate performance obligation with deferred revenue.

questions.question: Under dollar-value LIFO, inventory is measured in terms of:

options.B: Dollar value pools rather than specific goods
options.C: Replacement cost

questions.explanation: Dollar-value LIFO measures inventory in pools of dollar value rather than specific units. This allows companies with many products to use LIFO without tracking individual items. Layers are added at year-end prices.
questions.tip: DV-LIFO: Track dollar amounts, not units. Convert to base-year dollars to determine if layer added or reduced.

questions.question: Beginning inventory $100,000, purchases $400,000, sales $450,000, gross profit rate 30%. Estimated ending inventory using gross profit method is:
questions.tip: Gross profit method: Goods available - Estimated COGS = Ending inventory. COGS = Sales × Cost ratio.

questions.question: Under US GAAP, impairment of a long-lived asset is indicated when:

options.A: Fair value is less than carrying value
options.B: Undiscounted future cash flows are less than carrying value
options.C: The asset's market price has declined
options.D: The asset is older than its original estimated life

questions.explanation: US GAAP uses a two-step test: (1) Recoverability test - compare undiscounted cash flows to carrying value. If CV > undiscounted CFs, impairment exists. (2) Measure impairment as CV minus fair value.
questions.tip: US GAAP impairment: Step 1 = undiscounted CFs (screening). Step 2 = FV (measurement). IFRS goes directly to FV comparison.

questions.question: An exchange of assets has commercial substance if:

options.A: Both assets are similar in function
options.B: The future cash flows of the entity change significantly
options.C: No cash boot is involved
options.D: Both parties are in the same industry

questions.explanation: Commercial substance exists when the entity's future cash flows change significantly in timing, amount, or risk. If commercial substance exists, recognize gain/loss and record new asset at fair value.
questions.tip: Commercial substance = cash flows change. Has substance: Use FV, recognize gain. Lacks substance: Use CV, defer gain.

questions.question: Under US GAAP, costs incurred for research and development activities are generally:

options.A: Capitalized and amortized over the expected benefit period
options.B: Expensed as incurred
options.C: Capitalized only if technological feasibility is established
options.D: Deferred until a patent is obtained

questions.explanation: US GAAP requires most R&D costs to be expensed as incurred due to uncertainty about future benefits. Exception: Software development costs are capitalized after technological feasibility is established.
questions.tip: R&D = expense. Software: After tech feasibility, capitalize. Before tech feasibility, expense.

questions.question: Costs of developing an advertising campaign should be:

options.B: Expensed as incurred or when first aired
options.C: Allocated over the campaign period
options.D: Recorded as prepaid expense until the campaign ends

questions.explanation: Advertising costs are expensed as incurred or when advertising first takes place. Direct-response advertising may be capitalized if specific criteria are met, but general advertising is expensed.
questions.tip: Advertising: Generally expense as incurred. Direct-response may be capitalized if reliably measurable benefits.

questions.question: An investor owns 40% of an investee. The investee reports net income of $100,000 and pays dividends of $30,000. The investor's investment account increases by:
questions.explanation: Equity method: Investment increases by share of income ($100,000 × 40% = $40,000) and decreases by share of dividends ($30,000 × 40% = $12,000). Net increase = $40,000 - $12,000 = $28,000.
questions.tip: Equity method: +Share of income, -Share of dividends. Dividends reduce investment, not income.

questions.conceptTested: Credit loss model for debt securities
questions.question: Under the current expected credit loss (CECL) model, credit losses on held-to-maturity debt securities are:

options.B: Recognized based on expected lifetime credit losses upon purchase
options.C: Not recognized until the security is sold
options.D: Recognized only for securities with market value declines

questions.explanation: CECL requires recognizing expected credit losses based on historical information, current conditions, and reasonable forecasts at acquisition. This is a forward-looking model replacing the incurred loss model.
questions.tip: CECL: Recognize expected losses immediately (forward-looking). Old model: Recognize when incurred (backward-looking).

questions.question: For a sale-leaseback transaction to qualify as a sale under ASC 842, the transfer must meet:

options.B: The revenue recognition criteria for a sale under ASC 606
options.C: The fair value test only

questions.explanation: A sale-leaseback qualifies as a sale only if the transfer of the asset satisfies ASC 606 criteria for when a performance obligation is satisfied. If not, it's treated as a financing arrangement.
questions.tip: Sale-leaseback: Must be a 'sale' under ASC 606. Otherwise, treat as financing (no sale, no gain).

questions.question: A lessor classifies a lease as sales-type. At lease commencement, the lessor recognizes:

options.A: Only lease receivable and deferred revenue
options.B: Selling profit or loss, lease receivable, and removes the asset
options.C: Only rental income over the lease term
options.D: A lease liability and right-of-use asset

questions.explanation: In a sales-type lease, the lessor recognizes: (1) Net investment in lease (receivable), (2) Derecognizes the asset, (3) Recognizes selling profit or loss (if any) at commencement.
questions.tip: Lessor sales-type: Recognize profit/loss upfront, derecognize asset. Direct financing: No profit upfront. Operating: Straight-line income.

questions.question: Under ASU 2020-06, convertible debt that is not accounted for using the fair value option is generally:

options.A: Separated into debt and equity components
options.B: Recorded entirely as a liability with no separate equity component
options.C: Recorded at fair value with changes in income

questions.explanation: ASU 2020-06 simplified convertible debt accounting by eliminating most separation models. Most convertible debt is now recorded as a single liability (unless fair value option is elected or specific exceptions apply).
questions.tip: ASU 2020-06: Simplified convertible debt. Single liability, no BCF separation for most convertibles.

questions.question: When a creditor grants a concession in a troubled debt restructuring involving modification of terms, the creditor:

options.B: May need to recognize an impairment loss
options.C: Continues at original terms until maturity

questions.explanation: In a TDR, the creditor may recognize an impairment loss if the present value of expected future cash flows (at the original effective rate) is less than the carrying amount of the receivable.
questions.tip: TDR creditor: Compare PV of new terms to carrying value. If PV < CV, recognize impairment loss.

questions.question: In a quasi-reorganization, a company with a retained earnings deficit:

options.B: Revalues assets to fair value and eliminates the deficit using paid-in capital
options.C: Issues new stock to cover the deficit

questions.explanation: A quasi-reorganization allows a fresh start without formal bankruptcy. Assets are revalued to fair value, the deficit is eliminated against paid-in capital, and retained earnings starts at zero (dated for 10 years).
questions.tip: Quasi-reorganization: Fresh start. Revalue assets, eliminate deficit via APIC, RE starts at $0 (dated).

questions.question: A company has 10,000 shares of 6% cumulative preferred stock ($100 par). No dividends were paid in Year 1. In Year 2, $150,000 of dividends are declared. Common shareholders receive:
questions.explanation: Preferred dividend = 10,000 × $100 × 6% = $60,000/year. Year 1 arrears + Year 2 = $60,000 + $60,000 = $120,000 to preferred. Common receives $150,000 - $120,000 = $30,000. Wait - let me recalculate: $150,000 - $120,000 = $30,000 to common.
questions.tip: Cumulative preferred: Pay arrears first, then current year, remainder to common.

questions.question: Interest income from municipal bonds creates:

options.B: A deferred tax liability
options.C: A permanent difference with no deferred tax effect
options.D: A temporary difference reversing in future years

questions.explanation: Municipal bond interest is permanently tax-exempt. It creates a permanent difference (book income ≠ taxable income forever) with no deferred tax consequence. Only temporary differences create DTAs or DTLs.
questions.tip: Permanent = never reverses (municipal interest, fines). Temporary = reverses in future (depreciation timing).

questions.question: When enacted tax rates change, existing deferred tax assets and liabilities are:

options.B: Adjusted immediately with the effect in income from continuing operations
options.C: Adjusted in other comprehensive income
options.D: Restated in prior period financial statements

questions.explanation: When enacted rates change, deferred taxes are immediately remeasured using the new rate. The adjustment is recognized in income from continuing operations (unless related to items originally in OCI).
questions.tip: Rate change: Remeasure DTAs/DTLs immediately. Effect usually goes to income (continuing operations).

questions.question: When a government issues a purchase order, the entry under encumbrance accounting is:

options.B: Debit Encumbrances, Credit Budgetary Fund Balance Reserved for Encumbrances
options.C: Debit Supplies, Credit Accounts Payable
options.D: No entry until goods are received

questions.explanation: Encumbrance accounting reserves funds for committed purchases. When a PO is issued: Dr. Encumbrances, Cr. Budgetary Fund Balance Reserved. When goods arrive, reverse and record the actual expenditure.
questions.tip: Encumbrance = reservation of funds. PO issued: Record encumbrance. Goods received: Reverse encumbrance, record expenditure.

questions.question: Under GASB, sales tax revenue is recognized when:

options.B: The underlying exchange transaction occurs and resources are available
options.C: Cash is collected from taxpayers

questions.explanation: Derived tax revenues (sales tax, income tax) are recognized when the underlying exchange occurs (sale, income earned) AND resources are available (collected within 60 days of year-end typically).
questions.tip: Derived tax revenues: Recognize when exchange occurs + available (usually 60-day availability period).

questions.question: An NFP should recognize contributed services as revenue when:

options.B: The services create or enhance nonfinancial assets OR require specialized skills and would otherwise be purchased
options.C: The volunteer requests recognition
options.D: The services are provided by licensed professionals only

questions.explanation: Contributed services are recognized only if: (1) they create or enhance a nonfinancial asset, OR (2) they require specialized skills, are provided by those with such skills, and would typically be purchased if not donated.
questions.tip: Contributed services: Recognize if enhance assets OR specialized skills that would be purchased. General volunteering = disclose only.

questions.question: An NFP receives $50,000 to distribute to another specified organization. The NFP should record:

options.B: A liability for the amount to be passed through
options.C: Both revenue and expense of $50,000

questions.explanation: When an NFP acts as an agent (pass-through), it recognizes a liability, not revenue. The recipient NFP recognizes revenue. Variance power or discretion would change this treatment.
questions.tip: Agent/pass-through = liability. If NFP has variance power or discretion, recognize as revenue with restriction.

questions.question: A company had 100,000 shares outstanding on January 1. On July 1, it issued 20,000 additional shares. The weighted average shares for the year is:
questions.explanation: WACS = (100,000 × 12/12) + (20,000 × 6/12) = 100,000 + 10,000 = 110,000. New shares are weighted from issue date to year-end.
questions.tip: WACS: Weight shares by time outstanding. Stock dividends/splits = retroactive adjustment (not weighted).

questions.question: When calculating diluted EPS using the if-converted method for convertible bonds, the numerator is adjusted by:

options.A: Adding back the bond interest expense, net of tax
options.B: Subtracting the bond interest expense
options.C: Adding the face value of the bonds

questions.explanation: If-converted method: Assume bonds converted at beginning of year. Add back after-tax interest (interest wouldn't have been paid). Add convertible shares to denominator. Include only if dilutive.
questions.tip: If-converted: Add back after-tax interest to numerator, add convertible shares to denominator. Test for dilution.

questions.question: Discovery of a material error in previously issued financial statements requires:

options.A: Prospective adjustment from the current period forward
options.B: Restatement of prior period financial statements
options.C: Cumulative catch-up adjustment in current period income

questions.explanation: Material errors are corrected by restating prior period financial statements. The beginning retained earnings of the earliest period presented is adjusted, and comparative statements are corrected.
questions.tip: Errors = restate prior periods. Changes in estimate = prospective. Changes in principle = usually retrospective.

questions.question: A change from FIFO to LIFO inventory method requires:

options.B: Prospective application only
options.C: Disclosure but no restatement (impracticability exception often applies)
options.D: Cumulative effect adjustment in current year

questions.explanation: While changes in accounting principle generally require retrospective application, FIFO to LIFO is an exception because prior period LIFO costs are typically not determinable. Apply prospectively from the change date.
questions.tip: FIFO to LIFO: Generally prospective (impracticable to restate). LIFO to FIFO: Retrospective application.

questions.question: Which input would be classified as Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy?

options.A: Quoted price for an identical asset in an active market
options.B: Quoted price for a similar asset in an active market
options.C: Company's own projections of future cash flows

questions.explanation: Level 2 inputs include: quoted prices for similar assets/liabilities, quoted prices in inactive markets, or observable market data. Level 1 = identical assets in active markets. Level 3 = unobservable inputs.
questions.tip: Level 1: Identical/active. Level 2: Similar/active or quoted/inactive or observable. Level 3: Unobservable.

questions.question: Form 10-K must include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Management's Discussion and Analysis (MD&A)
options.C: Quarterly financial data

questions.explanation: Form 10-K includes audited annual financial statements, MD&A, risk factors, executive compensation, and certifications. Quarterly data is in Form 10-Q. However, selected quarterly data may be included in 10-K notes.
questions.tip: 10-K = annual report (audited). 10-Q = quarterly report (reviewed). 8-K = current events.

questions.question: A parent sells inventory to a subsidiary at a profit. At year-end, the subsidiary still holds the inventory. On consolidation:

options.A: The profit is recognized because it's an arm's length transaction
options.B: The intercompany sale and profit in ending inventory must be eliminated
options.C: Only the intercompany receivable/payable is eliminated
options.D: The profit is split between parent and NCI

questions.explanation: Intercompany transactions (sales, expenses) and unrealized profit in assets still held within the group are eliminated on consolidation. Consolidation presents the group as a single economic entity.
questions.tip: Consolidation: Eliminate intercompany transactions and unrealized profit. Recognize profit when sold outside the group.

questions.question: Push-down accounting refers to recording acquisition adjustments:

options.A: Only in the parent's separate financial statements
options.B: In the subsidiary's own financial statements
options.C: Only in consolidated financial statements

questions.explanation: Push-down accounting adjusts the subsidiary's books to reflect acquisition-date fair values and goodwill. This is optional under GAAP when a change in control occurs but required for SEC filings in certain circumstances.
questions.tip: Push-down: FV adjustments pushed to sub's own books. Optional in GAAP, may be required for SEC.

questions.question: Under IFRS, which inventory cost flow assumption is NOT permitted?

options.B: Weighted average
options.C: Last-in, first-out (LIFO)

questions.explanation: IFRS prohibits LIFO because it may not reflect actual physical flow and can result in outdated balance sheet values. US GAAP permits LIFO. This is a significant GAAP/IFRS difference.
questions.tip: IFRS: No LIFO allowed. US GAAP: LIFO permitted. Major GAAP/IFRS difference affecting multinationals.

questions.question: Under IFRS, development costs meeting specified criteria are:

options.B: Capitalized as an intangible asset
options.C: Recorded as inventory

questions.explanation: IFRS requires capitalization of development costs when specific criteria are met (technical feasibility, intention to complete, ability to use/sell, probable future benefits, resources available, reliable measurement). US GAAP expenses most R&D.
questions.tip: IFRS: Capitalize development if criteria met. US GAAP: Expense R&D (except software after tech feasibility).

questions.question: Which item is reported in other comprehensive income?

options.B: Foreign currency translation adjustment
options.C: Gain on sale of equipment

questions.explanation: OCI includes: Foreign currency translation adjustments, unrealized gains/losses on AFS debt securities, pension adjustments (prior service cost, actuarial gains/losses), and effective portion of cash flow hedges.
questions.tip: OCI: Translation, AFS debt securities, pensions, cash flow hedges. Trading securities = income, not OCI.

questions.question: A component of an entity qualifies as a discontinued operation when it:

options.B: Is disposed of or classified as held for sale and represents a strategic shift
options.C: Is unprofitable for two consecutive years
options.D: Is located in a different geographic region

questions.explanation: Discontinued operations require: (1) disposal or held for sale classification, AND (2) represents a strategic shift with major effect on operations/financial results (such as a major line of business or geographical area).
questions.tip: Discontinued = disposed/held for sale + strategic shift. Not just any sold segment qualifies.

questions.question: Related party disclosures must include:

options.A: Fair value of all related party assets
options.B: Nature of relationship and description of transactions
options.C: Personal financial statements of related parties

questions.explanation: Related party disclosures require: (1) nature of the relationship, (2) description of transactions, (3) dollar amounts, (4) amounts due to/from related parties. Cannot claim terms are equivalent to arm's length unless verified.
questions.tip: Related party disclosure: Who, what, how much. Cannot assert arm's length terms unless substantiated.
